stream_context.summary: Kaze wrapped up functional work on Course 14 “Handmade Heights” (star names, Peach NPC logic) and began high-level design for Course 15, tentatively called “Astral Arcade.”  Discussion focused on mechanics (low-gravity volumes, black-hole warps, pinball and arcade mini-games), asset reuse, music integration, and keeping the ROM within a 64 MB N64-era limit.

development_findings.summary: Course 14 is declared finished except for a Peach cut-out animation that Zeina/Yuki agreed to create.
development_findings.quote: Course 14 is done. All that's missing is one asset, which I'm still waiting for from Yuki.

development_findings.summary: New Peach NPC logic: after Mario defeats three Shy Guys, talking to Peach now gives a Yoshi coin instead of a star; a bug caused by an unset variable (listhead) was located and fixed.
development_findings.quote: Wait I never set listhead? No wonder it didn't work – that explains everything.

development_findings.summary: Early star-name pass completed for Handmade Heights; final list exported through FAST64.

Course 15 design goals: a rocket-shaped central building, outside low-gravity zones marked by scrolling green lines, black-hole portals between areas, pinball bumpers/flippers as platforms, and arcade cabinets that teleport Mario into mini-games (e.g., Whack-a-Mole, Asteroids-style moon explosion).
development_findings.quote: What if there were game machines you find in the main area and you jump into them and then you get into the game like that?

development_findings.summary: Memory strategy: development uses the 8 MB Expansion Pak to avoid 4 MB optimisation, but final build must not exceed the original 64 MB cartridge size; current ROM sits at 58 MB after removing unused songs.
development_findings.quote: I want to stick to the 64 megabyte limit because that's what they worked with back in the day … the ROM is 58 megabytes now, easy.

development_findings.summary: Music pipeline: Badub’s pre-rendered track “Funky Space Casino” was imported for Course 15; Kaze and community collaborators located an accurate loop point before embedding.
development_findings.quote: This is a Funky Space Casino.  Holly, where's the looping point?

development_findings.summary: Entire project codebase has been migrated to C; Kaze noted recent FAST64 inaccuracies and plans to report them.

context_findings.summary: Kaze values creative freedom over corporate stability; he would only work at Nintendo for $110-120k+ and if modding/personal projects remained possible.
context_findings.quote: For working at Nintendo to be worth it … I would have to be like $110,000 or $120,000 … and I’d still want to make my own games.

context_findings.summary: He vents frustration with Nintendo’s litigation against streamers, hoping the company loses to set a better industry precedent.
context_findings.quote: Honestly … I hope Nintendo loses because that would be a net positive for the entire video-gaming industry.

context_findings.summary: Personal routine: maintains a written workout schedule (pull-ups, calf raises, dips) and mentions diminished eloquence after “four years not talking.”
context_findings.quote: I used to be a really eloquent speaker … after I spent four years not talking at all I became a lot worse at it.

context_findings.summary: Excited about imminent Twitter monetisation and optimistic about a forthcoming video on the N64’s hidden half-megabyte of RAM.
context_findings.quote: Fellas, we are so close to getting monetized on Twitter … I think the hidden half-megabyte video is gonna be a banger.

biobak.summary: Joined stream discussion on Course 15 visuals; earlier ‘Gadabox’ slide assets (satellites, asteroids) that Biobak made will be reused.
biobak.quote: The flying asteroids here – you're probably going to keep seeing in the hack … The satellites definitely.

badub.summary: Supplied multiple course tracks, notably “Funky Space Casino” for Course 15, already uploaded to SoundCloud; Kaze relies on Badub for exact loop-point data.
badub.quote: Did Badub ever send me a song for this? … Alright, this is the one.

zeina.summary: Under the handle Yuki, she volunteered to animate Peach’s happy/sad cut-out; Kaze is waiting on this asset to finalise Course 14.
zeina.quote: Yuki wanted to do the drawing so I'm waiting for that. If she doesn't then we consider this done in a day’s stream.

key_stories.title: The Peach Coin Bug
key_stories.summary: While wiring Peach’s post-battle reward, Mario kept receiving nothing. Kaze traced the issue to an uninitialised pointer, fixed it live, and confirmed the Yoshi-coin spawn.
key_stories.challenge: Peach should grant a Yoshi coin after three Shy Guys are defeated, but no object met the condition.
key_stories.process: Debugged the object list, discovered ‘listhead’ was never set, added initialisation, re-compiled.
key_stories.outcome: Peach now reliably spawns a Yoshi coin, unlocking completion of Course 14 pending animation polish.
key_stories.key_quote: Wait I never set listhead? No wonder it didn't work – that explains everything.

key_stories.title: Fitting a Modern Hack into 64 MB
key_stories.summary: Kaze balances modern ambitions with historical authenticity: he dev-tests with 8 MB RAM but insists the final ROM stay below 64 MB. After deleting unused music he brought the build down to 58 MB.
key_stories.challenge: Avoid exceeding the largest commercial N64 cartridge size while adding high-quality music and assets.
key_stories.process: Uses Expansion Pak during dev, prunes assets, converts songs to pre-rendered form, monitors FAST64 size read-outs.
key_stories.outcome: Current build is under budget, giving headroom for remaining levels and assets.
key_stories.key_quote: We have so much space left … that means our actual game is like 30 megabytes, not even.

key_stories.title: Imagining the Astral Arcade
key_stories.summary: Initial brainstorming session for Course 15 produced a vision of a rocket-mounted space arcade on Rainbow Road, featuring low gravity, black-hole warps, pinball platforms, and arcade cabinets whose mini-games reshape the overworld.
key_stories.challenge: Create a final main-game course that feels fresh and large without devolving into gimmicky 2D mini-games.
key_stories.process: Live design debate with chat and Biobak; listed star ideas, cut weaker concepts, anchored design around three external zones plus a central tower.
key_stories.outcome: Working title ‘Astral Arcade,’ core mechanics logged; asset and music baselines chosen for future implementation.
key_stories.key_quote: I want a big rocket in the middle and then outside there’s slides, low-gravity sections, rainbows flying around and asteroids.

open_questions.context: Kaze described marking low-gravity areas with ‘green lines scrolling up’ but hasn’t detailed how this will be technically or artistically realised.
questions: What exact physics changes occur inside a low-gravity volume?
How will players recognise the boundary intuitively?
Have you prototyped performance impact on real hardware?

open_questions.context: Black holes will connect distant parts of Course 15, yet no specifics on placement, activation, or reuse of existing code were given.
questions: Is the warp mechanic already coded in another level or is new tech needed?
Will players unlock warps permanently or per-visit?
How will the visual/ audio feedback differ from traditional warps?

open_questions.context: Course 14 is held up by Zeina’s Peach animations.
questions: What is the expected workload and style reference for the Peach cut-out motions?
Does Zeina need additional tooling or guidance?
Is there a contingency plan if the asset is delayed?

open_questions.context: Pre-rendered songs save CPU but cost ROM; current build is 58 MB with several courses left.
questions: How many more pre-rendered tracks can the ROM sustain?
Will any existing songs need to be down-sampled or converted to sequence format?
What criteria decide when a track is worth the extra space?

open_questions.context: Kaze teased a video and implied the hack could exploit this memory, but gave no details.
questions: What is the technical nature of this ‘hidden’ 512 KB?
Could Return to Yoshi’s Island practically utilise it on real hardware?
Would emulator inaccuracies block such an experiment?
